name: Marissa Froese
bio:
Nova Scotia,old farmhouse living. Small farmer. Wife, mama, home educator. Artist, nature lover. Wyndelin farm & gf kitchen. 
#wyndelinfarmsourdough

social_posts.post_text:
We’re getting a bit festive around here. Just a slow build up of Christmas pretties here and there. 

If you’ve been to our house, you know it’s beautifully old farmhouse wonderful but that it’s full of renovations in progress, thrifted and old mismatched furniture, and our slightly chaotic life “stuff”. 
I imagine our house finished and orderly sometimes and I’m always aiming for clean and organized but mostly I’m thankful for our home that welcomes and holds space for the people who are dear to me.

Is brass still all the rage fashion wise? I’m not sure but I was pretty happy to pick up this vintage brass picture holder for a few bucks the other day! It’s perfect for holding open a recipe book and then being tucked in the baking drawer when not in use. Plus it’s pretty. 
Speaking of recipe books, we still have quite a few copies of our books left and if you order this week, they should arrive in time for Christmas presents. We can even include a gift note for you!
(Wyndelin.ca or click the link in my bio.)

The girls rarely request actual cakes for their birthdays; doughnuts are often the request. 
Our birthdays are family oriented so an invite means the whole family is included. Given that Cecily is our social girl, her list always expands from what was our standard one family to four or five families. 50 doughnuts plus doughnut holes disappeared in a hurry!

(My old fashioned gluten free doughnut recipe can found in Everyday Celebrations at Wyndelin. All my recipe books (ebooks and softcover) can be purchased at wyndelin.ca. Link in bio)

39 journeys around the sun. I think a lot about life these days. What it means to live well for the time I have here while knowing that face to face Jesus will be more perfect than I can imagine. 
It’s such a juxtaposition to treasure this life while longing for the next. I have so incredibly much that brings me delight in my life. A husband and life partner who knows and loves me so well, who makes me laugh and thinks I’m funny and cute and smart and pretty. My kiddos who love and respect their quirky imperfect mama. My menagerie of animals who keep my spirits up on hard days. My family who loves me from afar and wishes to drag me back to BC. My friends who have shown themselves loyal and true. The beauty that surrounds me everyday. This community that loves me in this odd little space called Instagram. I’m a blessed woman and I hope that in small ways I bless others with this life I’ve been given.

Years ago when I started my first online business (handmade childrens clothes and accessories), I began the tradition of doing a birthday sale. It seems like a good tradition to carry on so for the next 24 hours, all of my recipe ebooks will be available for 50% off as well as 15% off my gluten free sourdough course. There are gifting options available for the gluten free people in your life! 
Visit wyndelin.ca or go to the link in my bio (no need for a code.). 
What’s your favourite birthday tradition?
As per usual the past few years we didn’t manage to get Christmas cards out. But we did get a family photo! So here’s my belated Merry Christmas and Happy New Year to each of you.

I often envy people who have a lot of discipline to do things like run every day rain or shine. I don’t have that kind of discipline. What I do have have is the discipline to milk my cow every day rain or shine. It’s kind of an discipline enforced outside of myself though so I’m not sure it actually counts as “self discipline”.
What is an area where you have discipline ? Or one where you’d like to be more self disciplined
I’ve never seen a pup so attached to a stuffie before. Cass brings hedgie with her when we go places and holds it like this until she feels comfortable. She’s the sweetest (not so) little thing.

My kids say “brown on brown. A bit matchy matchy.” While Dan calls me his nut brown rose (#namethattune) . And I’m so glad that I’m important to their world. 

I wish it hadn’t taken me so long to understand how small my sphere of influence could be to be valuable. 

I wish that I would have settled into the mundane tasks of caring for my family joyfully sooner. 

I wish I would’ve ignored the lies that being “just a mom” and “just a wife” weren’t enough, weren’t glorious when done with grace and service, years ago. 

I’m thankful that even amidst my growing pains and a times yucky resentment for the life that I in fact chose, that I had a good foundation. 

I’m glad that I learned to love anyway even when I didn’t “feel” like it. 
I’m glad that even with my bumps and blotches, my family still is drawn to me, feels loved by me. 

Sometimes setting the tone for my home feels daunting. I don’t always feel up to the task. But I can genuinely, genuinely say that this is a gift and a joy.

The sun has been as evasive as the snow this winter. When it does shine, it’s often during our school hours. We shamelessly forget the books and head outside, often drawn down to the river or to ramble with friends. 
School kids get snow days but the girls will remember “sun days” as part of their school days.

On January 25, 2020 I decided to share here with you all that I’d been diagnosed with breast cancer. Stage 3/4, hard to say which. 
In November, 2022 my interim oncologist told me that my scans had all come back clear. No new evidence of cancer and barring any changes, she would see me in 2025. 
In December I made a call to my surgeon regarding some new spots that I had found. Nodules and small masses. 
After lots of tests and scans, it’s become clear that cancer isn’t a distant memory. I have reoccurrence, new cancer, and metastatic disease. 
If that’s hard for you to read, know how hard it has been for me to wrap my head around. 
It’s possible to live with metastatic cancer for years, and at this point I’m choosing to focus on alternative treatments that I previously wasn’t prepared to try with the goal of doing what I can to slow the cancer growth while being able to keep my body strong and healthy for the duration of time I have left. 
Our family has had the hard conversations and will have more to come. This is not what we dreamed of for our life. But regardless of the outcome and the number of my days, we maintain hope. It’s a nearly impossible balancing act of moving forward living each day and working to live while also preparing to die. I do know that while there are times of sadness and tears, I don’t want anyone sitting around waiting for me to die. That’s not life. 
I intend to live my life well and when I leave this life it will be to see the one who sustains me and who loves me, my husband, my daughters and the rest of my loved ones more than I can fully understand. I believe that wholeheartedly. I will be with Jesus. That is how I’m able to continue to live a peace filled and joyful life even amidst the hardest grief. 
I believe it is still possible for my body to heal enough to sustain me for many years. But it means some not easy weeks ahead. This journey has changed me as a person. I don’t like it but I’m better for it. For now, I continue forward in hope and life. Thank you to each of you here in the space who love and who pray for me.

People say often that I’m so strong, so brave. Nights when I huddle in my bed wishing this would pass from me leave me wanting to protest and declare just how very weak and broken I am. I don’t want this hand. 

I want assurance of the life Dan and I have dreamed of together. I want to watch my girls grow into women, to explore their dreams, to marry, to have babies. I want to be a gramma. 

I want to skip the physical pain. I don’t want to prepare my family to say goodbye. I want to keep being “strong”. 

But sometimes I want to give up and say it’s too hard. Too hard to work to heal my struggling body. In the dark of the night, it feels easier to say “they’re right, my body is giving up.”. It feels easier to accept what I’m told is inevitable. I feel so so very weak in my spirit. 

But then in the light of morning, there’s new mercy and I can keep moving forward with what feels like supernatural courage. I think that’s the gift of each new day.

Aneliese and @helen_froese_ have been working on Aneliese’s quilt over the past few weeks and now that it’s at the hand quilting stage, Aneliese figures I could add some stitches as well. It’s sure not for the faint of fingers! 

I did manage to get a couple rows done before getting back to my healing protocol that’s currently a full time job. 

I slept under my grandma made quilts my entire youth and my girlies are blessed to do this alongside their gramma.

I’ve had some setbacks of late. Pain that limits my mobility. My oncology team was a wee bit horrified that rather than taking their advice to head to the hospital for more scans and tests, I chose to instead stick with the planned winter getaway. 

Working to heal my body isn’t looking the way that I hoped or imagined it to work. Partly related to separate back injuries that now come back to plague me. 

I don’t pretend to know which way this is going to go but I do know a couple of things. I love my daughters more than life itself. I will not have their last memories of me (if this is what they turn out to be) to be cancelled plans and hospital stays. Their memories of me will be of me doing my best to fill their childhood with love and presence. They’ll remember my smiles and laughter as much as they’ll remember my pain and adjustments to things like a wheelchair. 

Not because I’m amazing or a hero but because within so much that I can’t control, this I can control and offer.

I’ve started getting messages from people concerned about my quietness this past week. First we were just enjoying time together and then later into the week a severe increase in pain led us find that I have a spinal fracture. Right now the focus is on managing the pain. Then I’ll get back to healing protocols (which by the way have me feeling pretty excellent a lot of the time.). 
So that’s where I’m at. I wish I could talk baking or cow milking or gardening plans but here we are. I’m currently thinking about my ideal wheelchair features and learning how to give myself pain meds via butterfly IVs.

39 years of being the proud little sister of @jordanjdowney. I can’t quite explain how I’ve loved him, he was definitely my hero for many years and now he’s a good friend. Having him, @march_jenya, their kids here this past week was wonderful. Even though I was only able to come for short visits, there was no shortage of fun and conversation. Sharing time with our kids and spouses is as good or better than our years of digging in the dirt and building forts.💕

The last day of our vacation took Quite a turn as I woke up in the middle of the night to more extreme pain then I had experienced.
I went for care in the city where we were staying that night. Turns out the pain was because I fractured my spine. This is a cancer related spinal injury. Needless to say it is excruciatingly painful. I’m currently in the small palliative care unit in our little town, which while hard has been best.
We’re still having an incredibly hard time getting my pain under control but have made some progress the last day or so hopefully. Part of the issue with the pain meds as well as the pain is that I’m not able to communicate with anyone much. This includes answering messages. 
I’m having a clear moment now so I thought I’d share a quick moment to check in. (Though trust me, this has taken me over 15 minutes.) .
Anyways, thanks for all the love and care.💕Pray that I’ll be home within the next few days. Dan and friends have been working hard on getting our house accessible as making do no longer works.

What I want most right now is to be with my girls. Participating in all the moments including those more tumultuous teenager-y ones. I loved being a mama to babies and toddlers and then little kids. Now my arms and legs, big emotions and ideas pre-teen and teens are just as wonder-filled to me. 
If something makes me choke up without fail, it’s talking about them going through life without me. I don’t want to curate that future but I do want to have some plans in place just in case because every one needs their mama’s influence in life. 
I don’t want to be in this hospital bed at all but since I can’t even manageable scale uncomfortable be anywhere else, I so glad that I’m less five minutes down the road and the girl can come freely. Take the moments you can, even when they aren’t your ideal. Trust me, you’ll never regret time with your kids unless your attitude around that time is misplaced.

We’re still navigating my being in palliative care while I recover from the spinal fracture (possibly more than one). It takes it’s toll. Without a grandfather who’s taken over all my chores and so many other ways people are helping, I don’t know how we would survive. I know people do though. I’m just thankful for the people who have surrounded us. 

Also thankful for teenagers who capably make breakfast waffles for the family and then pack it up to serve me at the health centre.  I’m so blessed. 

And those At Wyndelin recipe books that Dan and I put so much into have paid for themselves over and over by giving the girls easy gluten free recipe access!

Edit: when I feel able, I post little snippets in my stories of what is going on but it’s fragmented even there. I can’t answer a lot of questions but feel free to message someone that you know knows me in real life if you’re out of the loop. 

I’m just here working hard to get stronger and we’ll enough to get home to keep trying to heal the cancer which fractured spine aside has a really hopeful outlook from multiple perspectives.

Things are getting set up for me to return home. A hospital bed, an accessible bathroom, occupational therapy has been over the main floor to make sure I can navigate. 

There’s still lots before I can be home permanently though. A month has changed so much. It’s the hardest thing to wrap my head around some times. 

I’d thought about end of life care, I hadn’t thought of care after a spinal fracture. I will heal. It’ll just look different for me. Will it be to complete healing or will it be that I always use a wheelchair at times? It changes so much and often my brain isn’t clear enough to process it. 

I don’t have a tidy package for you, I wish I had one for myself. This isn’t what  I had envisioned for my 40th year of life. 

But even as tears start to flow as I write this, God is good. He has been good to me. 
I know these thoughts are not what many of you followed me for but they are the ones that,  in my darkest moments of late, are what I have found to be true. So they are what I’ll share. 

I hope to be in this pictured room soon, our library. With it’s bright colours and newly added hospital bed surrounded by our books and my children.

Mornings are the slowest right now. I’m still getting up at five but there’s no morning chores or routine to be done before I know it. And I’d say morning is my favourite part of the day generally. 
Especially now that I am feeling better, I’ve decided not to fight it though. So I get up at five and slowly get dressed, make my bed, and do the things that I can while of course following what I’ve been told for bending and stretching etc.
Then I do my first laps of the morning, make a cup of tea and try to pretend that there aren’t still several hours left. Sometimes Dan comes in first thing to visit which certainly makes the morning speed by. All too soon, he has to get home for chores etc. But least we get a chance to chat.
This feels like forever but it too shall pass and interestingly, it has made the brutal starkness of cancer fadeaway some. I think maybe that’s a good thing.

With the help of @atopnorthmountain & @shady_anne, I walked outside with my walker yesterday. Our conversation was so wonderfully not about me or my injury or my cancer. It felt so normal even though they were keeping a close eye and I needed to use the wheelchair for the walk back.
 
I live in my head a lot and I analyze and think over everything, including this current stage of my life. I have said many times that I will use whatever accessibility aids I need in order to share life with my family. I still feel that way but there is no denying that this loss of independence takes it’s inner toll. 
And it’s not the part about others doing for me, it’s about trusting others to support my body in that I have until now been in control of.
 
 Until recently, I have never experienced sitting in a wheelchair, especially a tilt one like I’m using now, trusting that someone else would navigate me forward. I have to trust that they will pay attention to curbs and objects and bumps that will jar my body. I have to trust they can manage to push me up a hill and not lose me going down. I have to trust that if they step away, they won’t forget me and they will come back. That they will remember to set the brake upon stopping. These aren’t bad things, these lessons and trust, but they are a process that is a challenge for my independent self. 
As someone with bone cancer in my spine, the wheelchair I require will never allow me to be free wheeling Independent as much as I wish it would. So these are things that I have to work through and find the right place within my emotional and mental space for. 
But I’m thankful even within this that I am able to deal with it in an emotionally healthy way and with the steadfast support of those who love me and who are dedicated to this with me.

📸 @atopnorthmountain

I’m home now! One day short of a month, I was able to discharge. 
Some like to stick pretty close to me (I’m not complaining) so the living room is the current hang out spot where I have my chair. 

Being home is wonderful. It’s also very hard. I’m home and everything that I love to do is there waiting and I with a body that can’t. 

I feel depression wanting to slide in. To darken my days and make me sad and despondent here in my chair. 

But yet again, that’s just not the way that I can live. I have to make a choice yet again. I can’t milk my cow, I can’t make a meal, I can’t get out into my garden. But I can fold some laundry, I can advise and parent from my chair, I can make a cup of tea. I can choose to keep pushing back at the natural discouragement and keep finding all the good and the light. 

If you pray for me, pray for those things. For the strengthening of my mind and emotions alongside the strengthening of my spine and legs. 

Post script: I want to acknowledge that these are vulnerable posts for me to share. However, I think maybe they are common experiences for those going through similar to me. Not everyone can express what I do even if they feel it. I can to some extent and so I hope that it can offer a little insight. That’s a significant reason why I share as I do.

I’ve been going through photos and getting them printed off. 
Some of them are so incredibly sweet. Like Cecily at barely seven making her special peanut butter cookies. So little but so capable. 
I’ve had a few people say that going through photos and writing memories must be emotionally draining. I don’t find it to be so really. I’m not end of life prepping in my mind, I’m just taking opportunity to do the things I’ve not previously given time to. I suppose I could see the chance to do this as a silver lining to the very not silver loss of mobility. 
I do envy people who are good about doing photo albums or books every year….I’m about 13 years behind🫠.

We made our Good Friday hot cross buns (recipe from @naomiannedevlin ) yesterday. It was a bit of a group effort  in that I started them with Dan bringing me the ingredients and Aneliese and a friend finishing them when I ran out of steam. Oh but they were delicious as we sat around feasting on them. 
We had much conversation about the significance of the hot cross bun, how and why it became a Good Friday tradition. The cross is an obvious reminder but also the spices inside to remind us of Jesus’ time in the tomb, the orange peel to represent the bitterness of his death on the cross. 
As with any religious tradition or trapping, one can take part unthinkingly and even without belief (which is fine) or they can be markers or reminders of our faith. A symbol and conversation starter. Even munching on hot cross buns and talking theology is a gift.

It’s that time of year again! The pond always offers hours of spring fun for the girls, their friends and of course the dogs. Georgie loves going out on the kayak. 

There’s a muskrat who’s taken up residence which isn’t fantastic so hopefully all the activity on his previously quiet home will encourage him to relocate.

The week went from a super fun climbing comp for the girls to another pain session for me ending in some procedures at the bigger hospital and then back for a stay at the palliative unit in our little town. 

This has been really hard watching what feels like my life that I so love happen as I literally sit and watch it. Then the pain hits again and it’s hard to think of a lot else. 

I really didn’t figure in such pain and the fractures into how I processed the cancer journey. Pain that I couldn’t work to manage through movement. I expected pain with end of life but not at this stage. 

I feel somewhat torn with how I will proceed but I know that a moving, stronger body is one that feels better.
I know this could sound a bit vague but go to my stories to read more. 

I can think I know what I know and then I get a hairpin curve and have to rethink. But the truth and the good does not change.
We’re just here playing with kittens if you need us.

About six years ago an elderly friend gave me a bag of unfinished vintage colonial lady quilt squares that an even more elderly friend had given her years before. 

They are nice sturdy fabric and I thought it would make a sweet picnic quilt for the girls. However, they’ve stayed in the bag until this winter when I pulled them out one day to work on for a bit. 

Right now as I’m mostly needing to spend time sitting while I heal, I’ve pulled them out again. My blanket stitch is getting faster with each block! 

There’s some special about continuing and hopefully finishing a project that someone else clearly put a lot of work into. Plus it’s work that I can pick up and set down as I wish. 

Maybe just maybe, the girls can use it for a picnic this summer….we shall see. 

#vintagequilt #colonialladyquilt #coloniallady

My precious friend Katie died from a knee surgery complication. Trying to say goodbye from a distance has been more than I can hardly comprehend. Our hearts are broken. She has always loved so well. Auntie KT to the girls, she started writing them from Japan before they could read or write. From college years together to the visit we were going to have this summer, she has been one of the most special and dearest of women. I love you Katie, thank you for being you.

I’m slowly getting back into one of the things that I love today; cooking for my family. The things that you don’t always appreciate and treasure until it’s taken away. 

I can’t lift or bend so still need someone handy for things like that but I can still mix up a pretty delicious batch of gluten free biscuits! 

Also strawberry freezer jam from last summer and homemade butter? 😍

Phoebe & Charlie. I suspect they’re just getting started on their shenanigans and they did put themselves in this basket.
(These two are spoken for but we still have five others who will be ready for homes in a few weeks.)
We got to enjoy my parents visiting us here in NS for the first time in many years. Never a long enough visit and we miss them already but I’m so thankful they came.

I had hip surgery today (this is the picture I sent to the girls to let them know I made it through.). 

One of my doctors told me yesterday that I was so hopeful and fearless. But he didn’t know that within that I was also so scared of this surgery. Not of pain or it not going well in terms of improvement but of dying and leaving my girlies in such a sudden way. I hate that thought for them and especially after losing Katie this way it’s become so real. But there were so many prayers both for surgery and for peace for me. The peace did come, I was able to let go of the fear and go into surgery trusting that it be ok no matter what the outcome. But it was oh so hard.

And I get more days, more time, more flower bouquets and horse stories when I got home. I don’t take these days lightly.

Dan and I were talking about the envy that Instagram can generate within. Of course envy can be allowed to fester within from any point but we were specifically thinking of IG. It’s been a challenge for me of late to watch my farmy and gardening friend live out that part of their lives. I want that for myself and I can’t have it. 
It’s easy to make *legitimate* excuses for letting the envy build within. I’ve got cancer that’s essentially destroyed that part of my body, it’s so hard, so sad etc. 
And yet. I’m called to root out that envy and to live differently. 

It was actually a Jordan Peterson quote that made me aware of what I was doing. In a paraphrase, he basically said that even when life is really hard, we still have a moral obligation to live well. Which includes taking the focus off of ourselves and our hardship to think about others. 

That opened my eyes to the ways that I’ve been looking at myself and envying others to the point where bitterness is being allowed to slowly develop. 
And so I’m making some changes. How can I give some encouragement to my friends? Maybe it’s a quick comment on a picture just acknowledging their hard work. 
It’s making a concerted effort to point out good qualities in my daughters along with the direction I give. 
It’s affirming and noticing all the things that Dan does in our days. 

There are a significant number of ways where I need to focus my attention on “myself” and what I’ve got to do to try to get healthy. But I need to do that without building envy and selfishness in my heart. I’m not saying that it’s easy. But I am saying that it’s important and possible and the way that I’m called to live even in this hard time.

There was a conversation about doughnuts and next thing you know, Cecily was whipping up a batch in the afternoon and friends were coming for tea and doughnuts in the evening. 

Encourage hospitality in your kids. Give them the tools that they need and then let them do it. It doesn’t have to be perfect or just so. Your house doesn’t need to be spotless. They will gain so much from learning early on how to be hospitable without being self conscious. And sharing your home and table with others in this way is the very fibre of our communities. This is how we connect with others in healthy ways.

How do you help your kids offer hospitality? 

(Gluten-free doughnut recipe can be found in the bio link for my Everyday Celebrations at Wyndelin recipe book.)

Kittens on guard duty.  We are inundated with kitty cuteness for just a few more days and if you need a good laugh, I highly recommend you go to my stories right now. I haven’t laughed so well in a while. Thanks to kitten shenanigans. Trust me.

Have I told you how easy it would be for me to become a critical, demanding person from my chair? That I am in fact at times already that person? That just because I love my daughters and they love me, I don’t automatically become the person they want to be around?

It’s an ever humbling position to be in. The mother who guides and directs well from a place of immobility but who doesn’t make her expectations a yoke of criticism on her children. 

I’m not naturally someone who praises and builds up others, it makes me feel vulnerable and foolish to be honest. But I’m working at it and trust me I have plenty of time these days if I choose to take it. 

I need the girls and Dan’s help so so much. I also see so much of what needs to be done and I know how it needs to be done. I so easily go into the mode of direction giving but not appreciation. Forgetting that there are things I’ve done over and over that are new to them. That now it’s the juggle of his own work plus Dan trying to take on mine. Forgetting that kind words flowing from my heart will only make our home better, stingy words will only weaken it. 

I wish I could snap my fingers and make myself more naturally kinder and  good word giving. But I suspect there much character development within this for me if I seek it. 

So I’m working at it. I’m working at being the place my children want to linger. Where my husband leaves feeling refreshed. Where my friends leave feeling encouraged. It’s a process.

A week post op and I’m getting out in my garden! I was able to weed and cultivate a bed which is a huge improvement from too much pain and too fragile in the hips to pull a rake or a stubborn weed. I’m having visions of a modified summer of garden work and just last week, I couldn’t begin to imagine that. 

I’m beyond grateful for tools like my walker that allow me to figure out ways to do this. 

#accessiblegardening #metastaticbreastcancer #disabledgardening

I did radiation last Friday on my hips and pelvis. I think I expected it to be a breeze but I think I probably underestimated. 

I’m utterly exhausted. As in fall asleep constantly. I read today that sleep is important but movement equally so. So my little weights are back out, my walker helps me out around the house and we’ve still got a few kittens to help with naps. Phoebe the grey is here to stay and the orange one Archie is going to be taking a trip in a fishing boat to become an island cat. How children’s storybook is that?!

Anyway if you think of me, that’s where I’m at. My poor broken body feels like it could use a break.

Some of my dearest friends are gathered for the memorial of our precious friend Katie. I clearly could not travel to Portland because of my own health struggles. So instead of being there in person, I watched her memorial live and heard all the words of love for Katie as tears streamed. I bawled as my own words were read. 
And I continued with daily life. I don’t think I will ever stop missing Katie and wishing she were here. But somehow amidst grief and loss, we keep going. For me, I keep going in the faith that both Katie and I will one day be with Jesus. Unexpectedly, she is with him before me. 
I struggle at times with the life that I’ve been given, the difficulties I deal with each day. And yet I’m grateful for the days I’m given and for the people that I get to love and who love me. I’m thankful for the bits of work I’m able to do. I’m glad that even while it hurts so much, I get the memories of a friend like Katie, working in my kitchen, laughing and chatting. I’m thankful for each day that I get to keep going.

Eighteen years as husband and wife. And how I love him. They’ve been some pretty hard years and some pretty amazing years. Sometimes those together at once. He gives so much of himself and accepts what I give him so gracefully. 
Right now we’re in a hard stretch physical, mental, and emotional but we’re together and somehow continuing to find beauty within it. 
We’ve been given such a gift in each other and I love this man so much and am so grateful for these 18 years.

I’ve spent more days in the hospital lately while they work to get my pain levels under control and my hemoglobin levels up. Honestly I don’t really know what’s going on and my doctors say that they don’t really either. It’s hard. I hate being in the hospital but on the same note, I don’t want my family to have to watch helplessly. 
But for now, I’m home again. I’m still working on getting stronger and if nothing else, enjoying the veranda as I never have before. I can deadhead geraniums and I can listen to childish tales. I’m working on cultivating a continuous joyful spirit both for myself and for my family. And because I believe it is how I can live like Jesus right now. 
It’s much easier when I’m enjoying life on my front porch than when I’m in a hospital bed but I’m trying for both places.

We’ve has some amazing summer moments alongside some where we weren’t sure if I was going to make it. This is life for us right now. It’s good and it’s hard. 

One of the life giving things for me has been going to the beach. I can’t swim or even wade because I’m not strong enough but I can plant my feet in the sand and let the water roll over them as I sit in the Hippocampe. Plus I can watch the kids which is the best thing ever I’ve learned. 
What’s been a good thing about summer for you?
Cecily stresses about our garden but how many thirteen year olds are solely responsible for a vegetable garden? She’s amazing really and I don’t tell her that enough.

Dan and Aneliese are working on a goat milking stand that my wheelchair can fit up to. It will roll under so that I’m at the right angle for milking. 
I’ll likely never milk my cow again but I’d love to be milking the goats this year.

I get asked often how I’m doing. It’s a tough one to answer because it changes often. A roller coaster if you will. I almost died a couple weeks ago. As in bring in your daughters kind of situation. I was ready. I was so tired, in so much pain and exhausted from fighting to stay alive. But then a little of this and a bit of that and I bounced back. 
Now this week, it looks like the new endocrine meds and a antibiotic clearing up an infection is giving me another go at life. I’m feeling better and all my blood numbers are improving. 
So how am I doing? I hope I’m living life with determination and joy while dying gracefully. Short of a miracle, I will not be cured and I’m going to die. But I may have a year or more…there’s no way really to know. So we do our best to accept and not be too thrown off kilter by the roller coaster. 
I’m enjoying life when I’m able. Resting a lot. Sometimes in excruciating pain. The details aren’t super important. Most people see me on a good day when I “look fantastic” and there’s the faithful few at my side during the bad days. Helping ease my pain, advocating for me, or just sticking close. 
Life really is a gift worth fighting for but death is just the beginning. I long to do both well.
Photo: a summer highlight of wading very briefly in our favorite lake.

I often get told strong I am. But I want to tell you about the people surrounding me. Like the church men who had an accessible and beautiful bathroom put in our house in the same week they learned that was keeping me in palliative care. Or the church women who make meals and keep us stocked in groceries every single week. Or Dan who patiently washes my hair, does my meds, rubs my feet, wheels me everywhere, and so much more with never a complaint. Or my daughters turned caregivers who still need me to be their mom and let them pile on my bed for all kinds of chats. Or friends who stay with me at the hospital and who don’t shy away from my pain even if it makes them cry. Or my respite who anticipates my needs better than I can. Or my doctors who come to my house to save me trips. Or my parents who helped get a vehicle that allows me to go places again. Or my siblings who travel across the country for short visits as tricky as it is to leave animals and jobs. If I’m strong, it’s because I’m not alone. I have support every step of the way. I did nothing to deserve this but I’m grateful, so very grateful.

Cass isn’t our best groomed dog because grooming the beasties was my job but she wins all the awards for sweetest. She just loves us and is so kindhearted. A bit slobbery at times. Pulls stuff around the yard on occasion but still, just so sweet and loving. Not to be fooled though, she is aware. She sat at attention most of the afternoon and barked regularly because she could hear a dog in our forest.

Have I mentioned how good I’m feeling? Literally we went from bringing the girls to my hospital room for a potential goodbye visit and my oncologist talking weeks to a sudden switch within two weeks. My platelets went from almost nothing to normal, my hemoglobin went from my heart working overtime to nearly normal. I feel like myself for the first time in months. My oncologist is now making a plan for the next year and hopeful for more.

Don’t get me wrong, I’m still sick and very much still have cancer. The rollercoaster is hard but I feel like God is giving me an unexpected reprieve. Is it all the prayers? Is it my previously healthy body fighting back? Is it merely a medical explanation? I don’t know but it sure feels almost miraculous. I can breath easy, I can walk around the house and some outside, I’m not sleeping more than I’m awake. It feels amazing. 

This morning I picked the blueberries and I loved how uneventful it was. Dan still hovered:) but I was fine. 

I’m afraid to hope but still so hopeful for the days to come. I can’t care for my home and family yet but maybe one day? Dan told me that in spring we can talk about my getting on a horse. Maybe I could milk again?

Thanks for praying and thanks for being here.

At last Mabel has had her calf! First I messed up her due date 2.5 weeks and then she’s a week past her actual due date. I and our vet predicted a big bull calf but instead she dropped a little heifer. At least that’s what Kathleen tells me. Dan’s away and I can’t get out there. Anyways, fifth healthy calf for Mabel and another speckle park since we’re so happy with their vigor. 
Mabel’s two years ago heifer also just had her calf and had a little 3/4 Guernsey and 1/4 Brown Swiss so Mabel’s also a grandmother. 
Tomorrow we’ll milk out colostrum for the freezer and go over Mama and baby but for now everything looks great. 
Name suggestions?

And just like that we’re back in milk. I’ve been the main milker but after I broke my back, Cecily took over and now she and Dan will be sharing the task. Much to my jealousy. 

Mabel has some edema as she always does after calving but her udder still looks nice and tight and high up. We hope to get many more milking years out of her. Not only is her milking personality fantastic, she has the best milk that I’ve ever tasted and I don’t say that just because she’s my cow. My mom, who has had many, many cows, agrees that her milk is so delicious.

I’ve been (with the help of friends) getting the art & craft room put together after we switched our bedroom to downstairs. 

I never imagined that I’d have the strength to do this and I’m excited for the girls to be inspired to create when they get back home. 

We’re a bit spoiled with all the room that we have now that we no longer run a guest house in half our house @wyndelin. Keep in mind that it also means more cleaning and more to take care but I’m not a tiny house, minimalist sorta girl when given the choice so I very much like it. I love creating spaces like this. 

Are you a tiny space, less cleaning or give me room to clean sort of person when given the choice?

It’s time to get back into cheese making with Mabel’s milk so today I did an Asiago and a Feta. I like to do them together as much of the timing is similar so less overwhelming to have two going at once. My respite and I got a bedroom clean during the down time and then she took care of elderberries while being available to help with any lifting. 
It’s a new and different season of being a farmer/farm wife but it’s working. It’s too easy to give up when it’s possible to get creative. I may not always be able to do this (today I used my walker seat) but we’ll deal when the time comes. For now, I’m making cheese!

The hospital bed was sent back yesterday so I’ve been trying to get our library back into it’s library self. With the help of a couple new pieces that I found on market place. Dan has been going hither and yon for work and it just so happened that a side by side secretary was near his work one day and the buffet five minutes away the next. 

I like old stuff and so does our house. How about you?

It’s pretty quiet and calm here right now but we’ve done all our prepping for the hurricane in case we have one. We’re mostly set for the important things like water and being able to cook as we have an barn gravity fed water and a propane stove but we fill jars with drinking water, have paper plates to cut down on dishes, phones and headlamps charged, lamps filled, candles and matches at the ready. Van tank filled, fuel for the generator in case we need it for freezers. 

There’s absolutely no use in freaking out and dramatics before a hurricane but it’s important to be prepared. We don’t have to spend a lot of time any more getting prepped but we make sure the dishes and laundry are done, the house is tidy, anything that can blow is secured, showers taken, animals in the barn or secure fences with shelter. We have easy to prepare food as if the power does go out it’s always a busy time after the storm. 
Prepare don’t panic. 

What would you add to a storm prep list?

My friend and I (with a lot of help from our kids) set up a new to us quilting stand and got going on a quilt that’s been in progress for a while. 
It’s made up of vintage embroidered linen and pieces of the girls linen clothes (mostly from @tsiomikkids ) from when they were smaller and wore things out from climbing trees and such. 
Dan’s mom pieced and sewed it plus started the hand quilting that we are continuing on with. It’s a big job. Like a very big job to hand quilt a queen sized quilt. Any bets on how long it’s gonna take? Can we sleep under it by Christmas?

Something to celebrate; my first time taking a walk unassisted since breaking my back at the beginning of the year. Frankly, we didn’t think I would walk more than a few steps again let alone take an actual walk outside. It was short and I was very tired after but I walked. For that I’m ever so grateful.

Grape gleaning day: most every year since the girls were wee toddlers, we’ve gleaned off our neighbors grape vines. He said today that he remembers the first time we came when one of them ran under the vines and came out with her apron full of grapes. 
We’re always grateful and they seem to enjoy sharing. 
Our other tradition is to watch a movie while doing the tedious work of pulling the grapes off the stems for juice and jelly making. Maybe some grape tarts too. 
In stories I was asked for usage beyond jelly and juice for grapes and I suggested spicy venison sauce, pie, and that’s about all I had. What do you suggest, haha beyond wine that is?

My view at the moment. The girls are working on their Institute of Excellence in Writing work whilst I make a simple lunch and grape juice at the same time. 
Perhaps it works for some people to multitask while teaching their children but I’ve learned it doesn’t work for me. That doesn’t mean I don’t still try it like I did today. I tell myself it’ll work but I can’t give my attention to them as I need to. 
We’re committed to doing the academics faithfully this fall. Are they learning plenty from preserving and harvesting and gardening etc.? Yes but there’s also a need I believe for the formal academic side as they get older and we’re focussing on that as we’ve missed a lot due to my sickness. 
I’m glad to do this. I’m grateful to teach my kids. I can hardly believe I’m able to can. It’s incredible. I personally just need to keep them separate. 

How do you who educate your kids at home whilst farming etc, manage it with your kids. I’d especially love to hear from some of the families doing so with older children.

Eleven years ago Dan walked a little brown and white pony up the rail trail to our house. That day he became the pony belonging to the three little Froese girls. They had their first riding lessons on him, first fall offs, brushed under branches on his naughty pony days, and he was a good pack pony to get apples from the orchard. 
He’s been much loved by many of the girls friends who secretly and not so secretly wished he was theirs. 
Then as ponies do, he got older and too stiff for riding but no less loved. 
Finally, he got too old to make another cold and wet winter comfortably. And so we said our goodbyes and gave him the kindest send off we could. 
I wish every girl could have a rascally but sweet pony like Max.

Dan made me garden beds from old oil tanks that I could work at standing or in my wheelchair. I ended up being so sick over the summer that the vegetables were mostly ignored after a very late planting. However, they grew their little hearts out and now there are tomatoes and peppers aplenty as well as the most beautiful basil I’ve ever seen. They likely won’t have a chance to ripen so I’m picking green and loving that I fill my skirt and wander back to the house by the strength of my own two legs. 
I know oil tanks might seem like an interesting garden option but they’re pretty perfect for my needs. 
What’s the most interesting or innovative way that you’ve gardened or seen done?

#raisedbedgarden #disabledgardening #harvest

I’ve been teaching our girls at home now for ten years. I only grow to love and treasure it more. 
Is it extremely tiring at times? Of course! Do the days feel mundane? Yes! Is it less fun and more academic these days? For sure! Am I forever glad that I chose to cease teaching other people’s children in order to spend these days with my own? 100 percent! 
I’ve been told so many times in a variety of ways by parents who wish they could be home with their children, teaching them, but believe that they can’t. 
I don’t pretend to know their situations entirely. I only know that our choice has required some sacrifices along with the benefits and anything that we’ve given up has been worth it. 
I know that I speak for both Dan and myself when I say that. I wish more parents believed in what they could offer their kids more. 
In the earlier years, we were more “open” to our kids eventually going to school but frankly, our intent now is to graduate all three from here at home even if I’m not here to see it. 
They are receiving the best education that they could and they are in the best place for their formative years (because yes, teen years are formative.) that they could possibly be. Big headed? Believe that if you wish but I assume you also firmly believe in what you are doing for your kids? Why would you expect less of me? 
We don’t educate at home for the smartest kids or the most perfect kids. I’m certainly not the smartest teacher and someone as imperfect as myself is hardly going to cut loose perfect kids. But I do believe this is best for them and that’s what I aim to give them. I’m blessed that they also love it and want to be here. 
Maybe you’re content with how you’ve chosen for your kids to be educated but if you aren’t, could I just encourage that you have what you need to bring your kids home and educate them? You can do it and you may just find that they thrive with it. You don’t have to have it all figured out in the first year. In fact, any teacher who would have you believe that is dishonest. You may find that it’s worth every sacrifice you make and that all of you love it. One thing that’s sure, you’ll never know if you don’t try it.

When Cecily was nine, we told her that when she was fourteen if she could show herself responsible enough to buy, train, and care for a dog herself, she could do so. 
We don’t need a third dog and had sort of forgotten that commitment we made to her but here we are, honouring our word to our girl because keeping our word to our children is worth so much. 
She chose a sweet Aussie mix girl and named her Aster after the blue aster flower that matches her eyes.

I had an oncology appointment to go over my most recent scans. And there’s pretty exciting news. My widespread, metastatic, and terminal cancer has shrunk significantly in size throughout my body. That’s pretty celebratory! I’m repeatedly told how well I look and how there seems to be a glow in my skin lately. And that’s because it seems to be so. 

I’m still powering through a lot of pills everyday and sometimes it feels a little much. I’m working for the discipline to fight past discomfort to strengthen my body with exercise like walking and weights. Right now my body is recovering and even though it’s hard to trust scans and papers after what we’ve been through, we’re still celebrating and want to let you celebrate with us. Thank God for shrinking tumours!

In a world that seems designed to teach teenagers that their siblings aren’t friends, that technology matters far more than a sunset, and that they destined to be a problem for their parents, a photo like this is gorgeous. 
I love parenting my teenagers. They have no social media and limited technology. They are friends with each other. It’s possible and it’s good. It’s not perfect because we are imperfect humans living in a world that has its priorities twisted but by the grace of God we go and I’ll treasure this sight. (They were wrestling twenty seconds later.)

I used to be afraid that I was only cheerful and bright spirited because I’d had life relatively easy. Then life started hitting me with some tingling blows but within my devastation, my spirit of joy and finding the bright side remained. Without a doubt I’ve cultivated it, I’ve turned to Jesus, and the scriptures I naturally turn to have endlessly called me to find joy and to praise the one who sustains me. 
Then I laid in a hospital bed holding my daughters close in love and good bye. With breath that seemed determined to fail I saw each word of love and each shared smile with Dan as possibly my last. Nurses were crying and I felt a little confused but they said that they had loved me too. 
That moment showed me that the Holy Spirit in me was giving me that strength I so wanted in my last moments. One of praise, one of courtesy, one of joy, one of sincere delight amidst terrible pain. The unlovely parts of myself seemed to fade away and I was refined in a way I never imagined even as tears fell. 
And now, now I came through that and here I live. It’s a bit bizarre. At times it’s actually harder now then before to seek joy and maintain a gracious spirit. I still have to cultivate it. 
I share this not as a pat on my back, I don’t care much for that. I share because I want to share my story of how continually seeking refinement into the person you desire (and are called ) to be, really does show itself in the end. I’m quite certain that hideous hearted  people have miraculous switches but I think that continuous seeking and whole hearted practice does leave you at the end still able to serve and love others. I can say that because I was given the odd opportunity to live through it. You might not have that opportunity and that’s ok. Trust that you are called to that place of refinement and grace as well. You really are.
It’s a pretty cute milk maid who has taken my place. I mean, I hope someday to get back at it but Cecily undoubtedly does an incredible job every day. And could this trio be any cuter?!

We were talking about how my farm posts kept going through cancer until this past February when I fractured my back. I never imagined that farming would end so completely for me. Today I felt well enough to kneel to plant some of our garlic from @twistedbrook but then needed to be helped off the ground and into my wheelchair to watch the rest. I’m well aware that my ability now is a bit of feel good doing and that aside from a miracle, I’ll never put in a day’s work farming or gardening again. I miss that. 

But I’m ok. Yes I shed a tear or two over it but I do think that one day I’ll garden in a whole and completely healed body. So I can wait for that and accept with gratitude what I can do now. 

These past three weeks have been illness and weakness filled so being able to get outside is in itself a blessing of recovering. I try to learn from others who learn to abide well in the body that they have even when it’s not what they’d choose. 

I wouldn’t choose this but I try to keep abiding in Jesus and the wholeness that he can give me.

We decided to do a little cyber Monday sale on our gluten free sourdough course. For one day only, we’re offering a 40% off discount on both the yearly and lifetime membership. 

Gluten free sourdough is a complete game changer when it comes to bread. Think soft, pliable bread without all the additives that go along with gluten free bread products. Just simple ingredients that most gluten free households have in their kitchen already. 

Go to wyndelin.ca or click the link in my bio to get your cyber deal!

Tomorrow it’s St Nicholas day so I put together our usual morning fun. If the girls need new shoes, they’ll find those but this year their shoes are good so just socks with a few sweets, a new puzzle and our traditional St Nicolas themed books, including some of the legends of the red garb fellow’s origin (hint; he wasn’t wearing red.)
Do you have traditions around St Nicolas day?

Phew it’s been a December already! With encouragement from friends, I decided to take a direct flight to visit my dear friend @kodystewartstudio. I know we like to avoid talk of death but from preparing for that very thing earlier this summer to flying on a plane this was a miracle visit altogether.

Then straight into birthdays and Christmas festivities! Cecily, Kathleen, and THEN I turn 40!! 

Cecily chose doughnuts over birthday cake and let me tell you I was happy to oblige with some added help and pumped out a triple batch of seventy doughnuts! 

I promise you, no one would ever know that these were gluten free but they may just scarf as many as they are allowed. Want to try making them? The recipe can be found in our Everyday celebrations at Wyndelin.ca. We’re out of paper copies but you can print the ebook, even getting fancy and printing it as a book. Or it makes a nice digital gift 🎁 too. 

And yes, we will be eating doughnuts for breakfast!

40 years old. I don’t generally give a lot of attention to the changing years but this one was hard won. Told at the beginning of it that according to the scans and speed at which the cancer was growing, I had weeks or months at best. Then I broke my back and thus began a flurry of hospital stays, one of which my girls were brought in for a potential “good bye”. And then in a miraculous change of medication and events, I began to get better. I got to see each of my girls birthdays (two of which are December). And now here I am, celebrating my birthday, getting ready for another Christmas, dreaming of the future. This is 40 for me. Here’s to 80.

One of our birthday traditions is to choose what we want for breakfast and I chose the Maple Granola from my breakfast recipe book along with yogurt and fruit. One of my favourites. 

Today as a little birthday gift to my IG friends I’m offering my three gluten free recipe ebooks at 50% off. It’s kind of a steal. You hop over to our website at Wyndelin.ca and just scroll down or go directly to the sale page in my bio. Gluten free foods that don’t taste like it from tried and true recipes!

On Saturday December 16th Marissa celebrated her 40th birthday in perfect Marissa style.  She started the day with a birthday breakfast (a family tradition)….then she had me drive her over to the barn to milk the cow (the first time in a long time)….she then proceeded to go thrifting with a good friend…followed by a birthday meal with friends where she could not help but be the host, even though she didn’t make the food. :)

It was great.  She was great. 

The following day her health took an unexpected sharp turn. On Friday December 22, surrounded by her family and friends, she went home to be with Jesus.

She fought long and hard to spend as much time as she could loving me and her girls. 

For a while now she has been sharing with so many of you here.  She did her best to be honest, like posting shots of the messy kitchen when we were taking pictures for her recipe books. 

She was always herself.  She cared deeply about the truth.  She loved real things like linen, wool, cast iron, and copper.  Somehow she seemed to know the favourite food of…everyone.  She was fiercely loyal.

She had an amazing knack for making incredible friends, and keeping them.

I don’t need to tell you about her, she already has.

We hope that this instagram glimpse into her life has inspired you to be better…to value real wholesome things not because it’s trendy but because it’s good…to stand up for the truth even when it’s not popular…to go to the beach with your kids even if you have to use a cane or a wheelchair…to really love your neighbour…maybe even to really love Jesus.  She wasn’t perfect, but she was really trying to be like Jesus.

I love her so very much.  Our girls love her so very much.  She showed us true strength so that even now that she’s gone we can carry on really living life to the fullest…supported by our family and incredible friends.

We miss her desperately.  We are filled with tears,  but we are also filled with memories that make us laugh.

We thank God for her and hope you will join us by doing the same.

Dan (and the girls)

Nova Scotia,old farmhouse living. Small farmer. Wife, mama, home educator. Artist, nature lover. Wyndelin farm & gf kitchen. 
#wyndelinfarmsourdough
